answers.answer: What are your exact lab results? Have they run a reverse T3 test on you? Please give your lab ranges with your test results. Labs seem to vary on this.
HiIn all honesty I am not sure, I am at the Drs again soon and I will find out........
Maybe diabetes?Just throwing ideas out there.
HeyNope I have been tested for it, and I am fine, so it is definately not that!!  There is something not quite right and very annoying........

question: Ok so here is my question?  I have hypothyroidism, and after telling my Dr for some time that my heart beat was too fast they finally did tests too discover I was taking too much....way too much, so: fine the tablets were reduced and although my heart beat is not as rappid as it was there are still problems, I still feel ill.  My heart beat can become fast one minute/day and perfectly normal for a few days after, My T4 was through the roof and my T3 was hardly noticable at all. Something somewhere is not balanced,  I am continuously hot......... when I am normally very cold, , and if I take a little nap.............say 20 minutes laid on the couch, when I wake up I feel drunk!!  and I dont drink!  Its awful and no one seems to be able to shed light on it. I have had an ultra sound on my thyroid and a brain scan and all normal........... iron levels are low but thats nothing new!!  The only extra annoying thing is that my back itches ....... although not as much lately and on my chest I have lightened spots........which is weird too..they have been there for about 2 years too, looks like dry skin but it is not..I can come over all funny one minute and feel perfectly fine the next, as soon as what ever it is calms down... which normally takes about an hour, but it is driving me nuts!!  I am not a person that is easily ill, I dont get colds, I have never been anxious in my life and I am so outgoing that what ever it is getting annoying and this has been on going for 2 years now,  Can anyone shed any light on this!!  There rant over lol!!!
title: Needing an answer about my thyroid
